summary: This document is an email chain from October 16, 2020, between an Assistant United States Attorney and a NY CART Coordinator/Senior Forensic Examiner. They are coordinating the review of image and video files extracted from electronic devices seized in the Jeffrey Epstein investigation, discussing technical issues with specific device processing and scheduling a call to plan the review.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney
persons.context: The prosecutor from the Southern District of New York is coordinating with a forensic examiner to review image and video files from seized Epstein devices, asking about missing data and scheduling a call.

persons.name: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: The forensic examiner is managing the technical processing of seized electronic devices, providing updates on device status (e.g., one drive is wiped, others are processing) and coordinating the handoff of data drives.

connections.person2: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
connections.description: Working together on the forensic review of electronic evidence in the Epstein case, coordinating logistics and technical aspects of data extraction and analysis.

events.title: Coordination for Epstein Evidence Review
events.description: Email exchange scheduling a call and discussing the status of forensic image and video extraction from multiple seized electronic devices related to the Epstein investigation.
personsInvolved: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner

keyFacts: Forensic examiners were processing image and video files from multiple electronic devices (e.g., NYC024342, NYC024329) seized in the Epstein investigation as of October 2020.
Device NYC024342 was identified as a wiped drive with no data recovered, indicating potential data destruction.
The prosecution and forensic team were actively coordinating to determine the most efficient way to review a large volume of seized files.
